headers.subject: [tosdr:832] Creative Commons as a TOS
headers.x-original-authentication-results: ls.google.com; spf=pass (google.com: domain of jamesmikedupont@googlemail.com designates internal as permitted sender) smtp.mail=jamesmikedupont@googlemail.com; dkim=pass header.i=@googlemail.com

html:
Hello,

I would like raise an issue here, many sites dont have a TOS directly they use creative commons copyleft or another form of copyleft.

The argument is that this is not a contract you agree with, but a license you accept if you exercise it and create derived works.
It is not a contract because you have no agreement between parties. 

"The GPL was designed as a license, rather than a contract"
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GNU_General_Public_License
http://www.gnu.org/philosophy/no-ip-ethos.html
http://fsfeurope.org/projects/gplv3/barcelona-moglen-transcript.en.html#q7-a-contract

We had a discussion on twitter here https://twitter.com/ToSDR/status/248378535142641664 and I would like to continue it in a better format.

my point is that copyleft gives you greater freedom, for example to share data from many sources with no contract with them. you can collect these sources together.

when you then introduce Contributor terms with the right to change the license in the future such as osmf has done, the entire copyleft breaks down because a third party cannot agree to the those terms. This is the different between a contributors agreement / contract and a copyleft license. 

thanks
mike


--
www.tos-dr.info // www.twitter.com/tosdr // www.github.com/Unhosted/ToS-DR

subject: Creative Commons as a TOS
text:
Hello,

I would like raise an issue here, many sites dont have a TOS directly they 
use creative commons copyleft or another form of copyleft.

The argument is that this is not a contract you agree with, but a license 
you accept if you exercise it and create derived works.
It is not a contract because you have no agreement between parties. 

"The GPL was designed as a license <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/License>, 
rather than a contract"
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GNU_General_Public_License
http://www.gnu.org/philosophy/no-ip-ethos.html
http://fsfeurope.org/projects/gplv3/barcelona-moglen-transcript.en.html#q7-a-contract

We had a discussion on twitter here 
https://twitter.com/ToSDR/status/248378535142641664 and I would like to 
continue it in a better format.

my point is that copyleft gives you greater freedom, for example to share 
data from many sources with no contract with them. you can collect these 
sources together.

when you then introduce Contributor terms with the right to change the 
license in the future such as osmf has done, the entire copyleft breaks 
down because a third party cannot agree to the those terms. This is the 
different between a contributors agreement / contract and a copyleft 
license. 

thanks
mike


--
